title: König's theorem (kinetics)
text:
In <a href="kinetics%20%28physics%29">kinetics</a>, König's theorem or König's decomposition is a mathematical relation derived by <a href="Johann%20Samuel%20K%C3%B6nig">Johann Samuel König</a> that assists with the calculations of angular momentum and kinetic energy of bodies and systems of particles.
For a system of particles.
The theorem is divided in two parts. 
First part of König's theorem.
The first part expresses the <a href="angular%20momentum">angular momentum</a> of a system as the sum of the <a href="angular%20momentum">angular momentum</a> of the <a href="centre%20of%20mass">centre of mass</a> and the <a href="angular%20momentum">angular momentum</a> applied to the particles relative to the <a href="center%20of%20mass">center of mass</a>.

Second part of König's theorem.
The second part expresses the <a href="kinetic%20energy">kinetic energy</a> of a system of particles in terms of the velocities of the individual particles and the <a href="centre%20of%20mass">centre of mass</a>.
Specifically, it states that the <a href="kinetic%20energy">kinetic energy</a> of a system of particles is the sum of the <a href="kinetic%20energy">kinetic energy</a> associated to the movement of the <a href="center%20of%20mass">center of mass</a> and the <a href="kinetic%20energy">kinetic energy</a> associated to the movement of the particles relative to the <a href="center%20of%20mass">center of mass</a>.
